Commands¶

class pyfrid.core.command.BaseCommand(app, *args, **kwargs)[source]¶

This is a base class for all types of commands. Commands are used in PyFRID as an interaction interface between users and application. Any command can be linked to other devices and modules with use_device and use_module functions by their aliases

app¶

Returns a reference to the parent

busy[source]¶

The property, which returns the value of busy flag

can(method)¶

Checks if a command with alias method can be performed by the object

completions()[source]¶

Returns completions for the current command as a tuple. The first item of the tuple is a list of lists with possible completions for every command parameter. The second item is a boolean flag which True value indicates that command parameters are repeatable. Example for the command like command parameter1 parameter2, where possible values of paramater1 are par11, par12 and possible values of parameter2 are par21, par22: >>> return ([[“par11”, “par12”], [“par21”,”par22”]], False)

debug(mesg)¶

Emits a debug message

error(mesg)¶

Emits an error message

exception(mesg)¶

Emits an exception message. This function must be executed only with exception handler, when a traceback information exists

execute(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Abstract execution handler. Put here a code which must be run during the command execution

get_permission_groups(permname)¶

Returns a list of permission groups (usergroups) for the permission. Permission is normally an alias of an action which corresponds to an alias of a command or any other special name related to the object.

grammar()[source]¶

Abstract grammar handler. It must return grammar rules which are understood by the VirtualMachineModule

has_error¶
has_exception¶
has_info¶
has_warning¶
info(mesg)¶

Emits a normal information message

initialize()¶

Initialize handler. Put here the code which must be run to initialize the object.

iterate_settings(permission='', fixed=False)¶

Yields settings depending on the permission of the current logged in user and fixed flag

lock()¶

Locks this object. While the object is locked and function acquires a new locking, the object will be blocked. This is useful for devices. For example during moving the device no further moving operation can be done.

locked¶
release()¶

Release handler. Put here the code which must be run to release the object.

runtime(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Abstract runtime handler. It returns a calculated time of execution of the command

settings(permission='')¶

This function returns a list of all settings, which are configurable by a user and have proper permissions

shutdown()¶

Shutdown handler

status()[source]¶

Standard status handler. It can be overwritten if needed

stop()¶

Stop handler. Put here the code which must be run to stop the object.

stopped¶
unlock()¶

Releases the lock of the object

validate(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Abstract validate handler. It must return True or False after validating of values of the command parameters

validate_setting(name, value=None, permission='', check_value=True)¶

It is the same function as in BaseObject class, but with permission control

warning(mesg)¶

Emits a warning message

class pyfrid.core.command.BaseThreadedCommand(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Base command class for a command with multiple parameters, like: command object1 parameter1 object2 parameter2 ... By default its grammar rule accepts OBJECT and VALUE repeated from one to infinite number of times and can be overwritten if necessary. A threaded command expects that every object to which it is applied, has special function-agent do_{command_alias} which does the actual job. If the numthreads parameter of the class is >1 the execution of the command for every OBJECT will be performed parallel in threads. The validation, runtime and completions handlers are automatic.
